conclusion: Introduction to the Stirling cycle and the isothermal processes A→B and C→D.
Understanding the isothermal process from C to D where temperature remains constant.
Explanation of the ideal gas law PV = nRT.
In an isothermal process, as volume increases, pressure decreases.
Pressure is related to molecular collisions with the wall.
Kinetic theory formula relating pressure to number density and average kinetic energy.
Pressure formula in kinetic theory: P = (1/3) n m ⟨v²⟩.
Number of molecules colliding is proportional to number density and average velocity.
Temperature is constant in an isothermal process, so average kinetic energy is constant.
Since ⟨v²⟩ is constant, ⟨v⟩ should also be constant.
Number of molecules colliding is proportional to number density n.
Pressure expression in kinetic theory: P = n k_b T.
Number density n = N/V, where N is the number of molecules.
Average kinetic energy per molecule and its relation to temperature.
Average velocity ⟨v⟩ is constant since temperature is constant.
Number of molecules colliding is proportional to N/V ⟨v⟩.
In an isothermal process, as volume increases, pressure decreases, but ⟨v⟩ remains constant.
Number of molecules colliding is proportional to N/V.
